title: This lecture concludes our survey of Mesopotamian civilization in the Bronze Age, focusing on the career of Hammurabi

We began by looking at the emergence of cities in Sumer (c. 3500 B.C.), and we are tracing the evolution of this civilization through the Sumerians, Akkadians, and Babylonians; later on in the course, we’ll bring in the Assyrians, who carried this civilization down to about 1200–1000 B.C. and the collapse of the Bronze Age
Hammurabi’s Babylon falls in the period of the Middle Bronze Age and is seen, in many ways, as the

title: The Middle Kingdom Scope: Rival dynasts clashed during the First Intermediate Period in Egypt (c
B.C.) so that nomarchs and priests looked for a return to order and justice (ma’at) under righteous pharaohs

author.literal: B.C.), prince of Thebes in Upper Egypt, founded Dynasty XI and reunified Egypt.

container-title: Yet the pharaohs of Thebes faced hostility in Lower Egypt; under Dynasty XIII, rebellions erupted in the Delta. In the fighting, Egyptian pharaohs and rebels summoned Canaanite allies or mercenaries, known as Hyksos. In 1674 B.C
note: the Hyksos, experts in chariot warfare and fortifications, captured Memphis and ruled as foreign lords over Egypt for more than a century (1674–1544 B.C.).
title: The usurper Amenemhet I

B.C.) founded the illustrious Dynasty XII of the Middle Kingdom, which transformed Egypt into a well-governed imperial order. The pharaohs of the Middle Kingdom, who ruled from Thebes, reorganized royal administration, sponsored irrigation and drainage projects, and promoted trade. They, too, required lavish royal burials, but in subterranean tombs bored out of the cliffs of the Valley of Kings on the west bank of the Nile and opposite Thebes. Foremost, the pharaohs were warriors, and Senworset III (r. 1878–1843 B.C.) advanced the frontier to the second cataract in Nubia, founding military colonies and recruiting Nubian infantry into the royal army. The copper mines of Sinai were exploited, and Canaanite ports were brought into tributary alliance

container-title: Religious reform at home put the Asiatic empire in jeopardy, as the Hittite emperor Šuppiluliumaš
Warrior pharaohs of Dynasty XIX met the Hittite challenge in Asia, but Rameses II
Hatshepsut
note: Scope: Khamose (r. 1570–1550 B.C.) founded Dynasty XVIII at Thebes and challenged the Hyksos kings of Avaris. Ahmose (r. c.

B.C.) achieved a stalemate at Kadesh and was forced to recognize Hittite supremacy in northern Syria. Rameses II and Merneptah (r. 1212–1200 B.C.) restored Egyptian rule in Palestine, but their heirs faced new invaders, the “Sea Peoples,” who ended Egyptian rule in Asia. Outline I. This lecture looks at the New Kingdom (c. 1550–1150s B.C.), the period when the Egyptian monarchy came to play a dominant role in the Middle East and Egypt reached its political and cultural zenith.
title: B.C.) forged a new royal army of chariots and Nubian infantry to expel the Hyksos and restore ma’at in Egypt. The pharaohs of Dynasty XVIII styled themselves as conquerors in memorial reliefs and painting and endowed the shrines of Amon, Ptah, and Ra with rich offerings of thanks
B.C.), the first queen to rule in her own right, halted expansion in favor of building projects and diplomacy. But she alienated the military elite at Thebes, and her nephew, Thutmose III

Thutmose III waged 17 campaigns in Asia and organized an Asiatic empire. The transformation of Egyptian values and material life climaxed in the religious reforms of Akhenaton (r. 1352–1335 B.C.), who aimed to exalt his majesty as the oracular voice of the sole god Aton. Akhenaton sought to break the aristocracy at Thebes and imposed his monotheistic cult by force
Akhenaton had compromised his dynasty and the empire, and his heirs would abandon the cult of Aton

container-title: The pharaohs of Dynasty XVIII, starting with the founder of the family, Khamose (r. 1570–1550 B.C.), adopted the military technology of the Hyksos and overthrew these foreign rulers
note: His successor, Ahmose (r. 1550–1544 B.C.), stormed Avaris and expelled the Hyksos.
title: We shall begin by looking at the pharaohs of Dynasty XVIII (1570–1293 B.C.). A. As you recall, Egypt had fallen under the control of Hyksos invaders, but the Hyksos ruled as a small military caste and never truly controlled the Nile valley. B. The princes of Thebes again emerged as a force of unity in the Nile valley

container-title: 1544–1520 B.C.), Thutmose I
note: For this reason, she pioneered methods of promoting the monarchy that prefigured the policies of the heretic pharaoh Akhenaton (r. 1352–1335 B.C.). She promoted arts, building and irrigation programs, and high-prestige trade. Her temple, Deir el-Bahri, depicts a diplomatic mission to Punt, that is, the Somalian coast. 3. We are not quite sure what happened to this remarkable woman, but she probably died of an illness in 1479 B.C. In her final years, however, she was already losing power, and Thutmose III was able to assert himself. In 1482 B.C., he led an enormous Egyptian army into Asia and defeated a coalition of Canaanite kings at the Battle of Megiddo. This victory opened a new era of Egyptian expansion in Asia.
title: The immediate successors of Ahmose

B.C.), conducted massive attacks into the region between the Mediterranean and the Jordan valley. D. The Egyptians also pushed deep into the Sudan. The region known as Kush, south of the third cataract, was organized as a viceroyalty, and Nubia was incorporated into Egypt. The territorial extent of Egypt was greatly enlarged from what it had been in the Old or Middle Kingdom. E. Imperial expansion halted briefly in the early 15th century B.C., during the reign of Queen Hatshepsut (r. 1489–1479 B.C.), daughter of Thutmose II, who ruled with the trappings of a male pharaoh. 1. Hatshepsut halted imperial expansion for a good reason: She was married to a royal consort, a nephew or half-brother, the future Thutmose III. He was proclaimed as a joint ruler, although he was considerably younger than Hatshepsut. Any military operations launched by Thutmose III would benefit him, not Hatshepsut, who risked losing her throne
The Akkadian emperors waged wars in this region, and starting from 1900 B.C. on, Assyrian merchants moved into the cities of central Asia Minor and established merchant communities

note: This kingdom was centered on the capital of Hattušas (Bogazkale), east of the Halys River.
title: Influences from Mesopotamia stimulated the Hittites to coalesce into kingdoms around 1700 B.C
The early Hittite kings unified central Asia Minor into a powerful confederation known as the Hittite Old Kingdom

title: Two of the early Hittite kings, Hattušiliš I

author.particle: emerged in the Aegean world on the island of

container-title: These rulers controlled hierarchical societies
note: adopted chariot warfare by 1500–1400 B.C., and acquired expertise in shipbuilding and ship warfare from the Minoans. Indeed, around 1400 B.C., Mycenaean Greeks sacked the palace of Cnossos. Thereafter, Crete was incorporated into a wider
title: The people of Crete devised a hierarchical society comparable to what we saw in the Near East. By 2100 B.C., the kings of the city of Cnossos had united the island and established control of the sea. C. The people of this civilization, the Minoans, were responsible for spreading their literacy and arts across the Aegean and into mainland Greece. From 1600 B.C., the people in southern and central Greece, that is, the Mycenaeans of the Greek heartland, adopted much of the civilization of Minoan Crete. D. What emerged in southern and central Greece was a series of about 12 kingdoms, each ruled by a wanax (“lord”

container-title: Throughout the 9th century B.C., Assyrian kings conducted massive raids in these areas to impose vassalage and exact tribute
title: Adad-nirari II (911–891 B.C.) launched a new series of wars in two directions: west, to bring the region between the Euphrates and the Mediterranean under Assyrian control, and east, toward Babylon

The self-image of Assyrian kings was one of great power. These rulers were often depicted on lion hunts, conducting campaigns, and subduing cities. The inscription for Ashur-nasirpal II (883–859 B.C.), for example, tells us of his brutal punishment of a rebellious city

note: The Neo-Hittite kingdoms were annexed between 745–717 B.C., as were the Aramaean kingdoms in Syria. D. The Assyrians also forced many of the states in the Near East to develop economically in order to pay
title: By the end of the 9th century B.C., the Assyrians began to encounter far more difficult coalitions that they were unable to defeat easily. A. In 853 B.C. at the Battle of Qarqar, for instance, King Shalmaneser III (858−824 B.C.) was checked by a coalition of 10 Syrian princes. B. When the Assyrian general Pul seized the throne in 745 B.C. under the dynastic name Tiglath-Pileser III (745–727 B.C.), the administration of the dynasty was reorganized, and the Assyrians began to conquer and rule methodically, rather than simply plundering their neighbors. C. Tiglath-Pileser III and his heirs incorporated many of the neighboring kingdoms as provinces

In this lecture, we conclude our study of the great civilizations of the ancient Near East with the Persian Empire. A. We shall use the reign of King Darius the Great (521–486 B.C.) as a stopping point because it represents the climax of developments going back some 30 centuries

note: notably Herodotus (c. 490–425 B.C.).
title: Darius ruled over a vast empire incorporating all three of the early river-valley civilizations. C. The kings of Persia were regarded as the noblest of all kings of the Near East and are well known to us from Greek historical authors

note: in the Near East. Finally, we’ll close with some remarks on the impact of these Near Eastern civilizations on the Western tradition.
title: We shall have three goals for this lecture: First, we’ll look at the Near East in the immediate aftermath of the destruction of the Assyrian Empire in 612 B.C. Then, we’ll explore the question of why the Persians emerged in the political order after Assyria as the eventual “winners
The Neo-Babylonians are best remembered for the victory of Nebuchadrezzar over the Hebrews of Judah and the deportation of the Jews from Jerusalem to Babylon in 586 B.C
Nebuchadrezzar is also remembered for the construction of the second of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon
Eventually, the Neo-Babylonian dynasty was also overthrown by Cyrus the Great of Persia
Babylon was put under siege and captured by the Persians. Babylon was later revered by the Persian aristocracy as its cultural capital

note: 2. Just as Egypt and Babylon had done, the Lydian kingdom eventually fell to the Persians. The last king of the Lydian dynasty who ruled at Sardes was Croesus (561–546 B.C.), legendary in the Greek tradition for his wealth and his philhellenism.
title: The third realm that came out of the old Assyrian Empire was in Asia Minor, the kingdom of the Lydians. The Lydians were a new people who had emerged in western Anatolia at the city of Sardes in the Hermus valley. 1. The Lydian kingdom consolidated Asia Minor by the middle of the 7th century B.C. after a series of migrations disrupted political structures in Anatolia. These were the migrations of the Cimmerians, a nomadic people who had constantly plagued the northern border of the Assyrian Empire

container-title: 1. Under Cyaxares (653–585 B.C.), the Medes united the various tribes of Iran and fielded effective cavalry armies. 2. The second king of the Medes, Astyges
note: B.C.), proved unpopular with his nobility and was overthrown by his vassal king and kinsman, Cyrus of Persia.
title: the Medes ruled in northwestern Iran and had their capital at Ecbatana (today Hamadan). The Persians and the Medes were related Iranian peoples, but the Medes took the lead in political organization because they had born the brunt of Assyrian attacks in the 8th and 7th centuries B.C

container-title: C. Cambyses died under mysterious circumstances in Egypt in 522 B.C., and his death sparked a rebellion across the nascent Persian Empire
note: Several candidates vied for the throne of the empire, but the one who triumphed was Darius I (521–486 B.C.). 1. Darius reorganized the Persian Empire, drawing upon all the institutions that we have studied in this course.
title: At the time, this political change in Iran was probably considered nothing more than a change of dynasty; however, Cyrus became one of the great conquerors of the Near East and was remembered as a wise king. A

Cyrus swiftly overthrew the Lydian kingdom and, about five years later, turned on Babylon; thus, he incorporated the Fertile Crescent and Anatolia into his realm. He died fighting the Scythians along his northeastern frontier. B. His son, Cambyses (530–522 B.C.), fell heir to Cyrus’s project of conquering Egypt. He invaded Egypt in 525 B.C. with the assistance of the Phoenician fleet and took out the Nile valley. The Persians were usually regarded as generous and tolerant conquerors, but this was not the case in Egypt

Yet in 499 B.C., Darius and his generals would be drawn into a rebellion by remote Greek subjects on the fringes of the empire. This event brought the Persians, first, into western Asia Minor, then, to Greece and would climax in the great invasion of King Xerxes (486–465 B.C
In that conflict, the king of Persia would ultimately be defeated by an unlikely coalition, the Greek city-states of Athens and Sparta and their allies
The Persian Empire
The Culture and Social Institutions of Ancient Iran

note: Cnossos (Greek: Knossos): Near modern Herakleion, this city emerged as the principal palace for the royal family that ruled Minoan Crete in 2100–1400 B.C. cuneiform: “Wedged shaped;” denotes the writing system devised by the Sumerians in 3500–3100 B.C. and recorded on clay tablets. The writing system was used for a number of languages, including Sumerian, Elamite,
title: B.C.): Refers to the period when bronze was the most sophisticated metal alloy produced by technology. Cataract: Refers to the five great falls that break the flow of the Nile valley. Egypt lies north of the first cataract. Chaldaeans: West Semitic pastoralists who settled in Babylonia c. 1100–900 B.C. and became the military elite of Babylon. The Chaldaean general Nabopolassar (r. 627–605 B.C.) overthrew Assyrian rule and founded the Chaldaean, or Neo-Babylonian, Empire. Cimmerians: Nomadic horsemen from southern Russia who crossed the Caucasus Mountains in the late 8th century B.C. and invaded Asia Minor and Mesopotamia. The Cimmerians shattered the kingdoms of Urartu and Phrygia and, thus, allowed for the rise of the Lydians as the major power in Asia Minor after 650 B.C

container-title: Middle and Late Bronze Ages. Hurrians: Speakers of an Asianic language written in cuneiform who settled in northern Syria and Mesopotamia c
title: Hittites: Descendants of Indo-European–speaking peoples who entered Asia Minor c. 2300–2100 B.C.; they unified Asia Minor into the first effective kingdom, then imperial order

They acted as cultural middlemen, transmitting Mesopotamian civilization to the Hittites of Asia Minor. They comprised the majority population of the Mitannian kingdom and later Neo-Hittite kingdoms in Syria

note: The Indo-European languages and Hamito-Semitic (or Afro-Asiatic) language families are so classified.
title: Foreigners;” Canaanite-speakers who conquered and ruled Egypt as Dynasty XVI (1674–1540 B.C.) from their fortress capital Avaris in the Delta. ideogram: A symbol representing a concept in writing systems. inflected language: Refers to a language in which grammatical function is denoted by sound changes within the root word

note: ka: The twin soul of the body destined for the afterlife in Egyptian religion.
title: The period of ancient history when iron was the most sophisticated metal (c. 1100 B.C.–500 A.D.). The Early Iron Age (c. 1000–500 B.C.) witnessed the political and cultural reordering of the Near East and Greece

note: Kassites: Indo-European speaking tribes of western Iran who conquered and ruled Babylonia in 1540–1157 B.C.
title: B.C.): The great battle between Pharaoh Rameses II (1279–1212 B.C.) and the Hittite emperor Muwatallis (r. 1295–1272 B.C.). It was a strategic victory for Muwatallis and confirmed Hittite conquests in northern Syria. karum: A consortium of merchants in Mesopotamia who established commercial settlements throughout the Near East
653–585 B.C.) in response to Assyrian aggression
B.C.): The decisive battle and siege by which Thutmose III smashed the Canaanite kings and conquered the Levant. The battle inspired the apocalyptic Armageddon of the Bible
Meluhha: Sumerian name for the Indus valley civilization (c

note: Middle Kingdom (c. 2050–1674 B.C.): Egypt under Dynasties XI–XV.
title: Land between the rivers;” denotes the arable between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers that today is Iraq

title: Denotes the civilization of the Bronze Age on Crete (2800–1400 B.C.); the name is derived from the legendary king Minos. Mitannians: Speakers of an Indo-Aryan language related to Sanskrit

container-title: and, after 1400 B.C., in the Aegean islands and Crete. The name is from Mycenae, the great palace that was the capital of Agamemnon in Greek legend
title: Mycenaean: Denotes the civilization of the Bronze Age in Greece (1600–1225 B.C

note: 3100 B.C. Neolithic Age (c. 7000–5000 B.C.): “New Stone Age;” this period witnessed the domestication of plants and animals and the shift to settled life in villages in the Near East.
title: Narmer palette: A ceremonial stone emblem that depicts Narmer’s conquest of Lower Egypt c

note: nome: One of the 30 districts of Egypt.
title: B.C.): Denotes the imperial age of Egypt under Dynasties XVIII–XX. nomarch: The district magistrate of a nome, who ruled by hereditary right until the reforms of the Middle Kingdom
2700–2200 B.C.): This period witnessed the flowering of Egyptian civilization under Dynasties III–VI; often designated the Pyramid Age

container-title: The term came into general use in the New Kingdom. Philistines: Refugees from Crete who were among the Sea Peoples who attacked Egypt in the Late Bronze Age
title: Persian Empire (550–330 B.C.): The last great Near Eastern empire, founded by Cyrus the Great (559–530 B.C.) and conquered by Alexander the Great (336–323 B.C.). See Achaemenid. Pharaoh: Egyptian per-aa, meaning “great house;” the title of respect to the Egyptian monarch

container-title: 1100–900 B.C. The Phrygians, from their capital Gordion, founded the first Anatolian kingdom of the Early Iron Age. pictogram: A symbol representing an object as a picture in a writing system
title: They settled the Levantine shore from Akko (Acre) to Gaza c. 1100–1000 B.C. and clashed with the Hebrews. phonogram: A symbol representing a sound in a writing system. Phrygians: Indo-European speakers who migrated from the Balkans into central Asia Minor after the collapse of the Hittite Empire c
3100–2800 B.C.): This period witnessed the spread of literacy and urban civilization in

title: These Hebrews were assimilated into the Assyrian population. See also Samaritans. thalassocracy: “Sea power

note: “Lord;” the Achaean or Mycenaean title for king, c. 1600–1225 B.C.
title: 3500–3100 B.C.): This period witnessed the emergence of true cities and literacy in Sumer
911–891 B.C.): King of Assyria; founded a new line of Neo-Assyrian kings who forged the first imperial order in the Near East during the Iron Age

note: Jezebel, were remembered as idolaters. They were overthrown in a coup by the general Jehu.
title: 873–852 B.C.): Omrid king of Israel; the first biblical figure named in contemporary Near Eastern records; a participant at the Battle of Qarqar and named in the stele of Mesha

container-title: Akhenaton
note: Amasis (r. 568–525 B.C.): Pharaoh of Egypt and the commander of the Greek mercenaries who seized power and overthrew the legitimate Dynasty XXVI. He died on the eve of the Persian invasion of Egypt.
title: B.C.): The second pharaoh of Dynasty XVIII; he expelled the Hyksos from the Delta and imposed his rule throughout Egypt

B.C.): Pharaoh of Dynasty XVIII, who succeeded with the dynastic name Amenhotep IV. In the sixth year of his reign, he changed his name to Akhenaton and proclaimed the monotheistic solar cult of Aton as the only religion in Egypt. His religious reforms plunged Egypt into civil war and enabled the Hittites to overrun northern Syria

container-title: Cyrus (r. 559–530 B.C.): “The Great;” he ascended the Persian throne as a Median vassal, but in 550 B.C., he conquered Media and was proclaimed Great King. He conquered Lydia in 546 B.C. and Babylonia in 539 B.C., founding the greatest empire of the ancient Near East. Darius (r. 521–486 B.C.): Great king of Persia and scion of the Achaemenid family, Darius was proclaimed king during the Great Revolt of 522–521 B.C. He restored order and reorganized the administration of the empire. Eannatum (c. 2450 B.C.): Ensi of Lagash who recorded his victory over the rival city Umma in the memorial Stele of Vultures. Entemena (c. 2400 B.C.): Ensi of Lagash and nephew and successor of Eannatum
Amenhotep
Ashur-uballit
note: he humbled the power of Umma. Esarhaddon (r. 681–669 B.C.): King of Assyria; he restored Babylon and waged tough frontier wars in Asia Minor against the Cimmerians. In 671–669 B.C., he invaded and conquered Egypt. Gilgamesh (Sumerian: Bilgames; c. 2700–2650 B.C.): Ensi of Uruk who inspired Sumerian and, later, Akkadian poets to celebrate his legendary combats and his quest for immortality.
title: B.C.): Founded Dynasty XII and initiated the recovery of royal power in Egypt
The Magnificent;” ruled the Egyptian Empire at its zenith under Dynasty XVIII. He favored the solar cult of Ra and moved to break the power of the great families at Thebes
669–631 B.C.): The last great Assyrian king, he built the great library of Nineveh and patronized arts and letters

B.C.): King of Assyria; asserted Assyrian independence in the wake of the defeat of the Mitannians by the Hittite king Šuppiluliumaš. Astyges (r. 585–550 B.C.): King of Media, he alienated the ruling elite and was overthrown by his nephew Cyrus, king of the Persians. Cambyses (r. 530–522 B.C.): Great king of Persia and son of Cyrus; he invaded and conquered Egypt. His accidental death sparked the Great Rebellion of 522–521 B.C. Croesus (r. 561–546 B.C.): Philhellene king of Lydia noted for his wealth; he blundered into a war with King Cyrus of Persia that resulted in his defeat and the conquest of his kingdom by Cyrus. Cyaxares (r. 653–585 B.C.): King of Media; he organized the Medes into the first effective cavalry army in history and allied with Nabopolassar of Babylon to destroy Assyrian power

B.C.): King of Babylon; he reunited Mesopotamia into the third territorial empire of the Bronze Age. Hammurabi, by issuing his law code and funding literary activities, made Akkadian the lingua franca of the Near East and transformed Babylon into its cultural and economic center

B.C.): The first Egyptian queen to rule in her own right as pharaoh. She was the daughter of Thutmose II (r. 1500–1489 B.C.), but she shared power with her consort and half-brother, Thutmose III. She halted imperial expansion and sought legitimacy by sponsoring building programs and cultural activities

container-title: Hattušiliš
note: Hezekiah (r. 727–698 B.C.): King of Judah; he is remembered as a righteous king who cleansed the Temple of Jerusalem of idolatry, smashing the brazen serpent. In 701 B.C., he was forced to purchase immunity and submit to
title: B.C.): Hittite king who consolidated control over the Hatti, founded Hattušas as his capital, and brought the petty dynasts of eastern Anatolia under his control

B.C.): Hittite king who concluded a treaty with Rameses II in 1257 B.C. that confirmed Hittite rule in northern Syria. He and his queen, Pudahepa, initiated religious reforms and erected the reliefs of the open-air sanctuary at Yazilikaya. Herodotus (c. 490–425 B.C.): “Father of history” and citizen of Halicarnassus, Herodotus wrote the first history, dealing with the clash between the Greeks and the Persians. His account contains a wealth of information on Asia Minor, Egypt, Babylonia, and Persia in the 6th and 5th centuries B.C
B.C.): Hittite king and brother of Mursiliš II; he fought Pharaoh Rameses II at Kadesh in 1275 and consolidated Hittite rule in Syria

container-title: In alliance with the Median king Cyaxares, he captured Nineveh and founded the Neo-Babylonian Empire
title: 627–605 B.C.): King of Babylon; a Chaldaean mercenary commander who rebelled against the Assyrians

2254–2218 B.C.): Akkadian emperor and grandson of Sargon I, he campaigned deep into Anatolia and northwestern Iran. He probably sacked the city of Ebla in Syria, and he pursued a generous policy of patronizing Sumerian shrines

container-title: Nebuchadrezzar II
B.C.): Chaldaean king of Babylon; he conquered the Levant and, in 587–586 B.C., captured and sacked Jerusalem, ending the Davidic dynasty and deporting the Hebrews
note: His reign is the setting for the biblical book of Daniel.
title: 3100 B.C.): Prince of Upper Egypt; he united Egypt and ruled as the first pharaoh

note: Omri and his heirs transformed Israel into an urban, bureaucratic kingdom, and he was remembered as a devotee of Yahweh.
title: 884–873 B.C.): King of Israel; a mercenary captain who seized the throne of Israel in the aftermath of the end of the Davidic line
2275–2195 B.C.): The last pharaoh of Dynasty VI, he ruled ineffectively over Egypt as nomarchs asserted their regional authority

664–610 B.C.): Was appointed as Assyrian client king of Egypt, but he soon declared independence and founded Dynasty XXVI, ruling from the capital Sais in the Delta. Psamtik was the first pharaoh to employ large numbers of Greek mercenaries

container-title: Rameses II (r. 1279–1212 B.C.): Pharaoh of Dynasty XIX, he fought the Hittites at the Battle of Kadesh in 1275 B.C., but in 1257 B.C., he agreed to a partition of Syria. He built the great temple of Abu Simbel in Nubia to celebrate his victories and restored Egyptian prestige and revenues
title: B.C.): Pharaoh of Egypt; the minister of Horemheb, he succeeded legally and founded Dynasty XIX

B.C.): Sargon I seized the throne of Agade and united the Akkadians into a kingdom. He conquered Sumer and Elam and imposed his hegemony over northern Iraq and Syria, forging the first territorial empire in Mesopotamia

note: Sargon II built a new palace and capital at Dur Sharrukin (modern Khorsabad).
title: Sargon II (721–705 B.C.): King of Assyria, he was likely a usurper who overthrew the legitimate monarch, Shalmaneser V. He took the throne name Sargon to assert his legitimacy and waged ruthless frontier wars against the Neo-Hittites and Urartu. He was slain in a frontier clash with the Cimmerians
705–681 B.C.): King of Assyria and son of Sargon II, he constructed the great palace at Nineveh

container-title: 701 B.C., he led an abortive invasion against Egypt
note: but he imposed his hegemony over the Aramaean princes and King Hezekiah of Judah.
title: He ruthlessly put down two Babylonian rebellions, in 703–700 and 694–689 B.C. He sacked, destroyed, and cursed Babylon, removing the cult statues to Nineveh

container-title: Shalmaneser III
note: Shulgi (r. 2094–2047 B.C.): King of Ur; he succeeded his father, Ur-nammu, as ruler of the Neo-Sumerian Empire. He created the royal chancery, patronized the shrines, and presided over the flowering of Sumerian letters. Snefru or Sneferu (Greek: Soris; c. 2610–2600 B.C.): First pharaoh of Dynasty IV; built the first true pyramids at Dahshur, the so-called Bent and Red Pyramids.
title: B.C.): The greatest pharaoh of Dynasty XII; he extended Egyptian power into Nubia, reformed royal administration, and initiated the reclamation of the arable of the Fayum
B.C.): King of Assyria; he campaigned against Babylon and the Neo-Hittite kingdoms, but Assyrian western expansion was checked by the Battle of Qarqar in 853 B.C

note: He also forged the imperial bureaucracy and provincial administration.
title: B.C.): Hittite king who humbled the Mitannian kingdom and exploited Egyptian weakness under Akhenaton to conquer northern Syria

note: The Hittite Empire fragmented soon after his death.
title: B.C.): Hittite king and second son of Hattušiliš III and Pudahepa; he completed the relief programs at Yazılıkaya

container-title: Tiglath-Pileser III
Tudhaliyas
Tukulti-Ninurta
note: Tutankhamun (r. 1335–1325 B.C.): Pharaoh of Dynasty XVIII; surmised to be the son of Akhenaton. He succeeded as a boy of 10 and, thus, was guided by his ministers to restore the old gods. He is celebrated for the fact that his tomb was excavated intact by Howard Carter in 1922.
title: B.C.): The greatest pharaoh of Dynasty XVIII, hailed as the “Napoleon of the Ancient Near East;” Thutmose III initiated Egyptian expansion into the Levant in the final years of his aging consort, Hatshepsut. His victory at Megiddo (1482 or 1457 B.C.) resulted in the advance of Egyptian arms to the upper Euphrates

B.C.): King of Assyria; originally the commander Pul, who seized the throne in a coup. Tiglath-Pileser reorganized the Assyrian army and administration and, thus, initiated a second period of imperial expansion
B.C.): Hittite king and son of Hattušiliš III, he sponsored religious reforms intended to create a sacral monarchy
B.C.): King of Assyria; he threatened Hittite frontiers and briefly conquered and ruled Babylon. He is remembered as a ferocious warrior and may have been the inspiration for Nimrod in Genesis

container-title: 480 B.C., he led the invasion of Greece, and the defeats sustained in 480–479 B.C. put Persian power in jeopardy. Ziusudra: The Sumerian Noah who built an ark to escape the flood sent by the gods to destroy mankind. He appears in a fragmentary Akkadian epic of 1600 B.C. under the name Atrahasis, “Surpassing in Wisdom.” Zoser of Djoser
note: B.C.): Pharaoh of Dynasty III; he commissioned his architect, Imhotep, to design the first pyramid, the so-called Step Pyramid, at Sakkara.
title: B.C.): King of the Third Dynasty of Ur, he cleared Sumer of barbarian invaders and forged the Neo-Sumerian Empire. He issued the first known law code in Mesopotamia. Utnaphistim: “I who found life;” the pious mortal of Shuruppak, rescued from the deluge by the god Ea in the Babylonian Epic of Gilgamesh. He and his wife dwelled in blessed Dilmum, where he was visited by Gilgamesh about the secret of immortality
486–465 B.C.): Son of Darius I and Atossa, daughter of Cyrus, Xerxes succeeded as Great King of Persia after the death of his father
Ancient Records of Egypt
Classic translation of inscriptions and sources
The Book of the Dead: An English Translation of the Chapters, Hymns, etc., of the Theban Recension
Classic translation and commentary
Myths from Mesopotamia: Creation, the Flood, Gilgamesh, and Others: A New Translation
Modern translations of the main cuneiform texts
The Epic of Gilgamesh
Best modern translation of the various texts on Gilgamesh; essential for studying the evolution of the epic
The Histories
Recommended translation of the “father of history,” who is the main source for the Near East under Persian rule
The only complete English translation of Hittite myths; includes discussion of Mesopotamian parallels

collection-title: An impressive collection of sources in translation; indispensable
title: Ancient Egyptian Literature: A Book of Readings
The Amarna Letters
Collection of administrative documents and diplomatic letters of the New Kingdom
The Ancient Near East: An Anthology of Texts and Pictures
Fundamental collection of translations of texts and illustrations of significant monuments
The Complete Tutankhamun: The King, the Tomb, the Royal Treasure
The best introduction to the objects and inscriptions of the only intact royal tomb
Poems of Heaven and Hell from Ancient Mesopotamia
Readable prose translation with excellent glossary and notes
The Literature of Ancient Egypt: An Anthology of Stories, Instructions, Stelae, Autobiographies, and Poetry

Translations of many important historical texts by one of the foremost American Egyptologists. Textbooks and Introductions: Burney, Charles. From Village to Empire: An Introduction to Near Eastern Archaeology
Emphasizes the material culture and achievements of modern archaeology in documenting the birth of civilization
The Cambridge Ancient History
Definitive, detailed studies of all relevant civilizations by leading scholars; extensive bibliographies, chronologies, and maps

note: Recommended introduction.
title: The Ancient Near East

note: also a provocative concluding essay on Hebrew and early Greek thought.
title: The Intellectual Adventure of Ancient Man: An Essay on Speculative Thought in the Ancient Near East
Thoughtful essays on religion and society in Mesopotamia and Egypt
The Ancient Near East: A History
Detailed political and institutional accounts with an emphasis on Mesopotamia and Egypt
The Art of the Ancient Near East
Best introduction to the arts of all civilizations
The Story of the Decipherment: From Egyptian Hieroglyphic to Linear B
Introduction to the reading of the earliest writing systems

note: Recommended atlas.
title: Historical Atlas of the Ancient World, 4,000,000 to 500 B.C

container-title: Origins of Civilization: Cohen, Mark N. The Food Crisis in Prehistory: Overpopulation and the Origin of Agriculture
title: Cultural Atlas of Mesopotamia and the Ancient Near East
Lavish atlas with excellent photographs, reconstructions, and plans of sites and monuments
Controversial thesis for the birth of agriculture and the domestication of animals
Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
An intriguing, if overstated, examination of the impact of disease, food supply, and climate in human development
From Foraging to Agriculture: The Levant at the End the Ice Age
Recommended study for the role of Levantine crops and animals
The Neolithic of the Near East
A readable account of the birth of agriculture
The Uruk Countryside
Model study of archaeological and survey information for the growth of early cities

note: Provocative study on the growth of Sumerian cities; recommended.
title: The Uruk World System: The Dynamics of Expansion of Early Mesopotamian Civilization

note: Fundamental on Babylon in the Chaldaean period.
title: The Reign of Nabondius, King of Babylon, 556−530 B.C
Two Old Babylonian Cities
The newest study on these two important cities of the Middle Bronze Age
The Lost World of Elam: Re-creation of a Vanished Civilization
Best introduction to the little-known civilization of southwestern Iran
Thoughtful discussion of the role of myth and ritual
The Treasures of Darkness: A History of Mesopotamian Religion
A classic, literate study
History Begins at Sumer
Introduction to Sumerian achievements
Sumerian Mythology
Recommended texts and discussion of distinct myths and worship of Sumerians
The Archaeology of Mesopotamia: From the Old Stone Age to the Persian Period
Recommended survey of the main sites and excavations
Foundations in the Dust: The Story of Mesopotamian Exploration
Recommended account of the discoveries of the first modern archaeologists in the 19th century
The Exact Sciences in Antiquity
Best introduction to mathematics and science in Mesopotamia
Archaic Bookkeeping: Early Writing and Techniques of Economic Administration in the Near East
Explores the role of literacy in economic and political developments
The Early History of the Ancient Near East, 9000−3000 B.C
Excellent discussion of the emergence of villages and cities
History of Assyria
Narrative political and military account based on royal inscriptions

note: Classic study on daily life and society.
title: Ancient Mesopotamia: Portrait of a Dead Civilization
Early Mesopotamia: Society and Economy at the Dawn of History
Recommended study on economic growth in early Sumer
Ancient Iraq
Best introduction, with excellent notes, bibliography, and maps
Sennacherib’s Palace without Rival at Nineveh
Excellent study of royal reliefs as art and propaganda
Civilization before Greece and Rome
Recommended discussion of economic and technological achievements, writing, and social institutions; emphasis on Mesopotamia
The Greatness That Was Babylon
Readable study of society and cultural achievements of Hammurabi’s Babylon
The Might That Was Assyria
Best modern introduction; reassesses Assyrian imperial institutions
Chiefdoms and Early States in the Near East: The Organizational Dynamics of Complexity
Crucial studies by American anthropologists on the transmission of Mesopotamian civilization to Anatolia
Evolution of the Gilgamesh Epic
Recommended for the literary life of Babylon and Assyria

container-title: Cyril. Egyptian Art: In the Days of the Pharaohs, 3100−320 B.C
title: Ur of the Chaldees: A Revised and Updated Edition of Sir Leonard Woolley’s Excavations at Ur
Exciting account of the discovery of the royal tombs at Ur by a pioneer archaeologist
Classic and well-illustrated study
Akhenaten: King of Egypt
The classic study superceded by Redford’s work
The Predynastic Origin of Egyptian Hieroglyphics
Seminal study in the origins of Egyptian writing
Building in Egypt: Pharaonic Stone Masonry
Recommended study for the construction of pyramids, Egyptian mathematics, and principles of Egyptian architecture

note: Important study on the origins of solar monotheism.
title: The Reign of Thutmose IV
Archaic Egypt
Recommended study for the origins of Egyptian civilization and the creation of the kingdom

note: Recommended introduction.
title: Hieroglyphics: The Writing of Ancient Egypt
Pharaoh Triumphant: The Life and Times of Ramesses II
Readable account of the pharaoh and the institutions of the Egyptian Empire

note: Important essays on administration and life in the New Kingdom.
publisher: Perspectives on His Reign. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press
title: Riddle of the Pyramids
Standard study with statistics on pyramids of the Old Kingdom. O’Connor, David, and Eric Cline

note: Supersedes all other studies on the pharaoh.
title: Akhenaton: Heretic Pharaoh
Brilliant study of the religious reforms of Akhenaton with reconstruction of texts
Egypt, Canaan, and Israel in Ancient Times
Most important study of the history of Egypt and the Hebrews in the past 50 years by a leading Egyptologist
The Art of Ancient Egypt
Recommended introduction, with an excellent bibliography
The Rise and Fall of the Middle Kingdom in Thebes
Classic study of the period
The Rise of Civilization in India and Pakistan
Emphasis on the long Neolithic traditions leading to the rise of the first cities of India
Ancient Cities of the Indus Valley Civilization
Recommended introduction; excellent maps and illustrations
Deciphering the Indus Script
The most current study on the Indus valley script
The Indus Civilization
Classic account of discovery and interpretation. Asia Minor and the Levant in the Bronze Age: Akurgala, Ekrem. The Art of the Hittites
Excellent study by the foremost Turkish archaeologist
The Sculpture and Sculptors of Yazilikaya
Important study on the religious reforms of Hattušiliš III
Ebla: A Revelation in Archaeology
Popular but well-argued introduction to this important Syrian city of the Early Bronze Age
Hattusha: The Capital of the Hittites
The indispensable study on the Hittite ritual capital
The Kingdom of the Hittites
The best modern account of political and military history

note: The companion study on society and economy.
title: Life and Society in the Hittite World
The Common Background of Greek and Hebrew Civilizations
Eccentric and unconvincing argument for common Greek and Hebrew cultural origins in the Canaanite world of the Middle Bronze Age
The Bearing of Their Texts on Western History
Unsupported argument for Minoan civilization as part of the Canaanite civilization of the Early and Middle Bronze Ages. Useful translation of Ugarite texts and myths
The Hittites
Classic introduction
Early Anatolia: The Archaeology of Asia Minor before the Greeks
Well-written survey of the earliest civilizations in Asia Minor, by a leading British archaeologist
Early Highland Peoples of Anatolia
Well-illustrated introduction to the first civilizations
The Hittites and Their Contemporaries in Asia Minor
Revisionist political geography and account now vitiated by the new discoveries clarifying Hittite boundaries
Ebla: An Empire Rediscovered
Well-written popular account of the excavations and site by the excavator
The Archaeology of Ancient Turkey
The best introduction, by a leading archaeologist
Ebla: A New Look at History
Interpretation of the Eblaite historical texts by the philologist of the excavation

container-title: Minoan Crete and Mycenaean Greece
title: The Hurrians
Recommended introduction; excellent illustrations
Troy and the Trojans
Well-written account by the American excavator; excellent illustrations and plans
The Preclassical: From Crete to Archaic Greece
Provocative and concise introduction to the evolution of Greek visual arts

note: Recommended introduction.
title: The Mycenaean World
The Palace of Minos
The definitive excavation report by one of the giants in archaeology

note: Recommended introduction.
title: Early Greece: The Bronze and Archaic Ages
Bryn Mawr
Best current scholarly opinion on the historical basis of the Trojan War
Mycenaeans and Minoans
Seminal revisionist thesis on the development of Aegean civilization in the Bronze Age

container-title: The End of the Bronze Age: Changes in Warfare and the Catastrophe ca. 1200 B.C
title: The Civilization of Ancient Crete
Recommended study of the archaeology and historical geography of Minoan Crete. Collapse of the Bronze Age: Drews, Robert
Seminal study, stressing the role of warfare and fiscal crisis in the fall of the great empires
Canaan and Israel in Ancient Times
Recommended chapters on the Sea Peoples and changing conditions at the end of the Bronze Age
Discontinuity in Greek Civilization
Provocative study arguing for climatic change in the collapse of the Bronze Age

note: Best modern account on the Phoenician impact in the Early Iron Age.
title: The Sea Peoples: Warriors of the Ancient Mediterranean, 1250−1150 B.C
Recommended study on migrations in the Late Bronze Age. Asia Minor and the Levant in the Iron Age
The Phoenicians and the West: Politics, Colonies, and Trade
Peoples of the Hill: Ancient Ararat and Caucasus
Excellent chapters on Urartu and the origins of Armenian civilization
People of the Sea: The Search for the Philistines
Recommended study on the current state of the evidence

container-title: Ann Arbor
note: Survey of the evolution of city life in Asia Minor; excellent on the Lydian kingdom.
title: From Croesus to Constantine: The Cities of Western Asia Minor and Their Arts in Greek and Roman Times
Sardis from Prehistoric to Roman Times: Results of the Archaeological Exploration of Sardis
Definitive study on the Lydian capital
The World of the Phoenicians
Recommended introduction by the foremost authority on the Phoenicians

note: Scholarly account on Urartu.
title: The Ancient Civilization of Urartu
The Gordion Excavations: Final Reports
The definitive account on the Phrygian capital and civilization
Understanding the Old Testament
The Pentateuch: An Introduction to the First Five Books of the Bible
Scholarly and readable study on the composition of the first five books
The World of Ancient Israel: Sociological, Anthropological and Political Perspectives
Controversial essay applying anthropological models to Hebrew society as presented in Scripture
Canaanite Myth and Hebrew Epic
Brilliant analysis of the relationship of older myths of the Levant to the Hebrew tradition by a leading biblical scholar
The Bible Unearthed: Archaeology’s New Vision of Ancient Israel and the Origin of Its Sacred Texts
Indispensable; supersedes previous studies on the relationship of archaeological evidence and biblical texts; excellent critical bibliography
Who Wrote the Bible?
Recommended popular introduction to the literary traditions
Archaeology of the Land of the Bible, 10,000−586 B C.E
Convenient discussion of the main sites, but the conclusions must be revised in light of Finkelstein and Silberman
Ancient Near Eastern Texts Relating to the Old Testament
Important parallel Near Eastern texts for understanding early Hebrew society
Egypt, Canaan, and Israel in Ancient Times
Brilliant analysis of Hebrew origins and relations with Egypt

container-title: Persian Empire: Boyce, Mary. A Historian of Zoroastrianism
note: The current definitive account.
title: The Hebrew Scriptures: An Introduction to Their Literature and Religious Ideas
Excellent for the spiritual and literary traditions
Persia and the Greeks: Defense of the West, 546−478 B.C
Recommended narrative account of Greek-Persian relations
The Cambridge History of Iran
Excellent narrative accounts and studies of all aspects of Iranian civilization down to the Sassanid Age

note: Recommended introduction.
title: The Persian Empire
The Culture and Social Institutions of Ancient Iran
Excellent on social and economic history, by two leading Soviet historians
The Heritage of Persia
Provocative introduction, stressing cultural continuity from the Achaemenid through the Buyid periods
Iran from the Earliest Times to the Islamic Conquest
Readable narrative account
History of the Persian Empire: Achaemenid Period
Still the best narrative of political history based on mastery of the Greek literary sources
Ancient Iraq
Excellent chapters on Mesopotamia under Persian rule
Sculptures and Sculptors of Persepolis
Main study for the ritual capital
